channel.title: Mac vs. PC
channel.description:
This discussion has been in a number of other topics, time to make it official? Which do you prefer, Mac or Pc? PC bashes Mac: http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=3e680_4807 -A bit of humor: http://www.gametrailers.com/player/usermovies/44464.html there is quite a few movies after it, so don't just close after it finished. This one is funny as shit at the end: http://www.gametrailers.com/player/usermovies/60387.html
Enough of the humor.
Lets get serous, http://www.gametrailers.com/player/usermovies/71296.html lawl. OK, which one do you like more, state 'true' facts why you like the one, and why you dislike the other.
LOL POKEMAN BATTLE: http://www.gametrailers.com/player/usermovies/69693.html

item.title: Mac vs. PC
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

The problem with macs is that the OS thinks it’s better than you. So the only people who can actually use macs are people who are even more arrogant than mac itself, to the point they think that anything thinking something else is better than THEY are is just ridiculous.

So basically, you have an asshole OS with an even bigger asshole user.

Read full topic

item.title: Mac vs. PC
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“juju, post:27, topic:133458”][quote author=The Un-Named link=topic=184716.msg1682853#msg1682853 date=1187411328]

normal users

Sorry for this rant, but I just gotta go ahead with it. You simply cannot apply normal, nerdy or whatever else to someone on the receiving end of the internet, personality is a very strange thing, you can be a computer expert, good at computer games, linux and even be a talented programmer along with having a perfect social life with a good job that doesn’t involve computers. Not everyone that uses lets say, Linux is a complete nerd with no life(assuming that’s what you mean about normal users).
[/quote]

nah, i was meaning that non- kernel/package developers are what I consider “normal” users - i wasn’t referring to any social standing or any crap like that. I was more or less saying that lots of people on this forum specifically seem to be pro-linux simply because “we can fix bugz ourself btr den mickysoft can lul” when i’d bet that most, if not all, havn’t looked at the kernel - let alone have the source on their machine.[/quote]

Yeah, sorry about that, I played a little RS before I went on the forums… Never again…

juju:

fanboys love to boast

Second paragraph in a nutshell.

But yeah, really I would just use Windows since I’ve never had to use mac nor get used to it.

Read full topic

item.title: Mac vs. PC
item.dc:creator: @exe626 exe626
item.description:
@exe626 wrote:

juju, you seen to be very intelligent, but the only reason more than half the people on this site even use Linux is because Moparisthebest said he uses it, and now they all wanted to be just like him. Really though, whats the point in having an open-source OS - or anything open-source, if you don’t use it?

Anyways, this discussion is between Mac and PC, not the OS you can put in it.

Read full topic

item.title: Mac vs. PC
item.dc:creator: @juju juju
item.description:
@juju wrote:

The Un-Named:

[quote author=juju link=topic=184716.msg1680816#msg1680816 date=1187340266]normal users

Sorry for this rant, but I just gotta go ahead with it. You simply cannot apply normal, nerdy or whatever else to someone on the receiving end of the internet, personality is a very strange thing, you can be a computer expert, good at computer games, linux and even be a talented programmer along with having a perfect social life with a good job that doesn’t involve computers. Not everyone that uses lets say, Linux is a complete nerd with no life(assuming that’s what you mean about normal users).[/quote]

nah, i was meaning that non- kernel/package developers are what I consider “normal” users - i wasn’t referring to any social standing or any crap like that. I was more or less saying that lots of people on this forum specifically seem to be pro-linux simply because “we can fix bugz ourself btr den mickysoft can lul” when i’d bet that most, if not all, havn’t looked at the kernel - let alone have the source on their machine.

The Un-Named:

I choose Linux. Why? Macs are great, but apple LOVE to boast about their products.

Linux fanboys love to boast about their OS and just love to start witchhunts on users who choose other OS’s. companies like red hat and novell also love to boast about their products, it’s just marketing. some “hardcore” Windows fanboys also love to ridicule users of other OS’s. microsoft loves to boast about windows too. it must mean all those os’s suck.

Read full topic

item.title: Mac vs. PC
item.dc:creator: @juju juju
item.description:
@juju wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:16, topic:133458”][quote author=xxlegitxx link=topic=184716.msg1677143#msg1677143 date=1187218680]

Windows may take long time to load with all it’s gui trinkets, but take a look at mac! You can’t even strip it down. In windows you can set the theme to 95 windows, in mac you’re stuck with the translucent slide in fade out 3d mesmirizing useless enviroment.

Well Windows is slow to begin with. Mac loads fast even with its ‘translucent slide in fade out 3d mesmerizing useless environment.’
[/quote]

It is easy to load fast when all of your hardware is proprietary and therefore don’t have to worry about these little things called ‘drivers’

I would never buy a mac because I can’t build one, you can’t upgrade them, you have to buy them and in a few years throw them away because they are old, did I even mention the price? They are more overpriced than Dell.

I have used windows since version 3.1, all the way up through XP SP2 (I tried vista as well, hated it) I know windows like the back of my hand, there is hardly anything that is doable that I can’t do or figure out. However after just a week (yes, give it 7 full days) of using kubuntu I was hooked on linux, and I have never looked back.

Linux, because it is open source, gives you customization unrivaled by anything else.

Want to run an OS on your PS2? your Wii? your xbox? hell even your gamecube? Sure, simply compile linux for your architecture and run with it. Want to run something not open source on anything besides the x86 architecture? You my friend are shit out of luck.

Don’t like the way your window manager looks? have you tried KDE, GNOME, Xfce, fluxbox or one of the other many managers there are out there? Still don’t like them? Write your own.

Having problems with some bug that you or someone else has discovered? If your OS is not open source have fun twiddling your thumbs while some lacky at apple or microsoft takes their sweet time getting around to it while you are left blowing in the wind. If you are running linux chances are someone else has already written a patch and submitted it to the kernel devs, if not you, yes even you, can write one.

Worried about security (see above as well)? With proprietary OS’s you have to trust the software engineers to have locked everything up, and you have to trust security companies that they have checked all loopholes. With open source code you can rest assured that thousands upon thousands of independent people from all over the world have reviewed the code, it is secure.

Any questions?[/quote]

uh, treating closed source development like it is the antichrist is stupid. Open source and closed source both have their merits.

how many normal users of linux(not kernel developers or package managers) out there have actually ever really looked at the kernel source/written a driver/patched a bug in the kernel? a very, very small amount.

windows can be reskinned completly, and, i’m guessing os x can too. hell, everything is configurable.

proprietary hardware is good in a way, without it you get huge amounts of driver issues - and with that comes security issues, as demonstrated with the recent bug in an ati driver that allowed a guy to access the vista kernel and load unsigned drivers(see: purple pill) - that affect all modern OS’s.

mac, windows and unix-like os’s all have their niches and they all specialise in different things, trying to compare them is like trying to compare apples and oranges.

sigh.

Read full topic

Windows may take long time to load with all it’s gui trinkets, but take a look at mac! You can’t even strip it down. In windows you can set the theme to 95 windows, in mac you’re stuck with the translucent slide in fade out 3d mesmirizing useless enviroment.
[/quote]

Well Windows is slow to begin with. Mac loads fast even with its ‘translucent slide in fade out 3d mesmerizing useless environment.’[/quote]

It is easy to load fast when all of your hardware is proprietary and therefore don’t have to worry about these little things called ‘drivers’

I would never buy a mac because I can’t build one, you can’t upgrade them, you have to buy them and in a few years throw them away because they are old, did I even mention the price? They are more overpriced than Dell.

I have used windows since version 3.1, all the way up through XP SP2 (I tried vista as well, hated it) I know windows like the back of my hand, there is hardly anything that is doable that I can’t do or figure out. However after just a week (yes, give it 7 full days) of using kubuntu I was hooked on linux, and I have never looked back.

Linux, because it is open source, gives you customization unrivaled by anything else.

Want to run an OS on your PS2? your Wii? your xbox? hell even your gamecube? Sure, simply compile linux for your architecture and run with it. Want to run something not open source on anything besides the x86 architecture? You my friend are shit out of luck.

Don’t like the way your window manager looks? have you tried KDE, GNOME, Xfce, fluxbox or one of the other many managers there are out there? Still don’t like them? Write your own.

Having problems with some bug that you or someone else has discovered? If your OS is not open source have fun twiddling your thumbs while some lacky at apple or microsoft takes their sweet time getting around to it while you are left blowing in the wind. If you are running linux chances are someone else has already written a patch and submitted it to the kernel devs, if not you, yes even you, can write one.

Worried about security (see above as well)? With proprietary OS’s you have to trust the software engineers to have locked everything up, and you have to trust security companies that they have checked all loopholes. With open source code you can rest assured that thousands upon thousands of independent people from all over the world have reviewed the code, it is secure.

Any questions?
